Project Number: 55305-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
November 2021 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Mongolia: Strengthening COVID-19 Pandemic 
Response and Resilient Health Systems 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 01122021143440788890 Generated Date: 06-Dec-2021 5:28:48 AM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Mongolia has requested support to strengthen its policy environment 
and human resources capacity to respond to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) crisis. The 
knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the Ministry of Health (MOH) of 
Mongolia to improve COVID-19 response and health system resilience through (i) health sector 
assessments for COVID-19 recovery, (ii) documentation of the COVID-19 response and related 
lessons, and (iii) strengthened capacity of government agencies involved in COVID-19 response. 
 
2.  The TA is aligned with the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) country partnership strategy 
for  Mongolia,  2021−2024;1 Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  Program  Health 
Strategy 2030;2 and the ADB Strategy 2030 operational priorities on addressing remaining 
poverty  and  reducing  inequalities,  accelerating  progress  in  gender  equality,  strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity, and fostering regional cooperation and integration.3 The 
TA is included in the country operations business plan for Mongolia, 2021;4 and is also aligned 
with  Mongolia’s  State Policy  on  Health,  2017–2026,  which  reaffirms sustained commitment 
toward improving health services for the population.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Mongolia’s COVID-19 situation and response. It is estimated that at least 60% of 
Mongolia’s population (totaling 1.98 million people) are at high risk of severe disease due to 
COVID-19. Of these, about 522,428 people are particularly vulnerable (i.e., frontline medical 
workers, emergency management staff, police and border military, state inspectors, the elderly, 
and individuals with comorbidities). The Government of Mongolia implemented strict measures to 
prevent the spread of COVID-19, with the first case of community transmission reported on 10 
November  2020.6 The  National  Deployment  and Vaccination Plan  against  COVID-19  is  an 
integral part of Mongolia’s overall national COVID-19 pandemic planning and prioritizes target 
groups  and  effective  strategies  for  vaccination.  Since  the  start  of  Mongolia’s  COVID-19 
vaccination program on 23 February 2021, Mongolia has achieved 69.4% COVID-19 vaccination 
coverage (one or two doses), and its high-risk groups have been immunized.7 
 
4.  While the COVID-19 vaccination program has been effective, Mongolia is still considered 
high risk by the World Health Organization (WHO), which in a 2017 evaluation, concluded that 
Mongolia’s core capacities for pandemic preparedness are limited, and that it remains vulnerable 
to emerging diseases and public health emergencies, with challenges in the readiness of the 
national systems to respond to large-scale, complex events in an effective and coordinated way.8 
 
1  The TA is related to strategic priority 1: foster inclusive social development and economic opportunity through 
supporting recovery from COVID-19 by providing training and strengthening emergency procedures. ADB. 2021. 
Country Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2021−2024—Laying Resilient Foundations for Inclusive and Sustainable 
Growth. Manila. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 22 November 2021.  
2  ADB. 2021. Enhancing Regional Health Cooperation under CAREC 2030: A Scoping Study. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
4  Originally known as Preparing the Health Security and Health Systems Project, the TA was renamed and changed 
from a transaction TA to a knowledge and support TA to reflect the support required due to the ongoing COVID-19 
pandemic based on country needs. ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia, 2021. Manila.  
5  Government of Mongolia. 2017. The State Policy on Health, 2017–2026. Ulaanbaatar. 
6  As of 24 November 2021, there have been a total of 378,833 cases and 1,969 deaths reported in Mongolia. 
7  Mongolia has received 214,400 doses of AstraZeneca and Covishield; 3,500,000 doses of Vero Cell; 296,010 doses 
of Pfizer BioNTech; and 60,000 doses of Sputnik-V. 
8  WHO. 2017. Joint External Evaluation of IHR Core Capacities of Mongolia. Geneva.

2 
Health  services  are  overwhelmed  with  hospital  beds;  and  intensive  care  unit  and  human 
resources are stretched beyond capacity. At the same time, Mongolia does not have laboratory 
facilities and capacity to determine variants, and specimens must be sent to neighboring countries 
for testing. Significant challenges persist and require continual commitment and support to 
prevent further outbreaks and a rise in cases. 
 
5.  Health  sector  constraints.  Systemic  issues  that  exist  across  the  health  sector  in 
Mongolia have led to challenges in COVID-19 pandemic treatment outcomes and management. 
Responsible government agencies lack training on cross-sector pandemic coordination and data 
sharing across ministries such as MOH, the National Emergency Management Agency, and the 
General Agency for Specialized Inspection. The pandemic has also highlighted governance, 
sustainability, and financing constraints in the health sector. Inefficiencies in hospital management 
and poor referral linkages between primary, secondary, and tertiary levels of care are also major 
constraints. Systemic health system issues have limited effective and efficient hospital treatment 
outcomes as the COVID-19 pandemic persists. 
 
6.  Health systems globally have experienced major setbacks and challenges in their ability 
to prepare and respond to the pandemic; this is exacerbated in countries such as Mongolia, where 
health sector challenges go beyond the pandemic and highlight a need for a more responsive, 
efficient, and sustainable health system to manage population health. Services such as routine 
immunization for children and reproductive health services for women have been affected as 
resources have shifted to address the pandemic. Women have been disproportionately affected 
by the pandemic, as 82% of the health workforce is female. The crisis has also increased gender-
based violence, as evidenced by the rise in hotline calls and the use of shelters by women. The 
TA assessments with gender focus will help to evaluate health system inefficiencies and propose 
policy actions to address those with gender-responsive policy measures. 
 
7.  ADB value addition. ADB has been a long-standing development partner for Mongolia, 
and  has  supported  the  health  sector  since  1993.  Through  strategic  partnerships  and  key 
investment projects, ADB has supported a range of public health interventions including in primary 
health care, drug safety and access, health information technology, human resources for health, 
health financing and insurance, and hospital rationalization and strategic planning. ADB has also 
supported key policy shifts, such as the switch from hospital-based curative services to more 
efficient and cost-effective primary health care; reform of health financing system to support 
universal health coverage and increase financial protection of people; rationalization of the 
hospital sector,  provision of increased autonomy for public hospitals to increase efficiency and 
quality of care; and improved patient safety through optimization of health services and regulation 
of medicines. ADB has impacted health sector strategic planning by supporting Mongolia’s Health 
Sector Master Plan, 2020−2026,9 and provided critical technical advice on key health sector 
policies and regulations, including for the Law on Medicines and Medical Devices, and the Medical 
Care and Services Law, passed by the Mongolian Parliament. With ADB’s policy support, the 
government has developed important health sector policy documents and amended respective 
laws and regulations. 
 
8.  ADB’s response to the COVID-19 pandemic. ADB’s support for COVID-19 in Mongolia 
includes rapid response measures such as (i) reallocation of $1.4 million under an existing health 
sector operation to support the procurement of emergency health equipment; (ii) a $0.225 million 
small-scale TA project for emergency response systems; (iii) a $2.5 million in grant support from 
 
9  ADB. Mongolia: Development of the Health Sector Master Plan, 2019−2027. During TA implementation, the final 
year of implementation for the masterplan was changed from 2027 to 2026.

3 
the Asia Pacific Disaster Response Facility (including $1.5 million from the Government of Japan); 
(iv) a $30 million loan to support disease control in the health sector; (v) a $26.4 million loan to 
strengthen social protection measures for vulnerable groups; (vi) a $73 million loan to further 
support additional social protection measures for poor and vulnerable groups; (vii) $100 million 
provided under ADB’s Comprehensive Response to the COVID-19 pandemic to support the 
government to manage the economic and health impacts; (viii) a $100 million policy-based loan 
to support medium- to long-term health sector reforms; (ix) $5 million in grant support to procure 
lab equipment and personal protective equipment; and (x) a $40 million Asia Pacific Vaccine 
Access Facility project to procure COVID-19 vaccines. 10 The TA will complement these response 
measures and strengthen the health system and determine and assess post COVID-19 recovery 
needs.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: a more responsive, efficient, and sustainable 
health system achieved (footnote 5). The TA will have the following outcome: policies on COVID-
19 response and public health preparedness strengthened. The TA will strengthen institutional 
capacity and conduct assessments on public hospital management, procurement and safety of 
medicines, pharmaceutical and vaccine regulation, public−private partnerships in health, and 
strategic health purchasing to move toward universal health coverage. Building resilient health 
systems for post-COVID-19 recovery will require a renewed focus on health policies that directly 
impact the efficiency and sustainability of delivering cost-effective health care to populations in 
need.11 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Resilient health systems for COVID-19 recovery assessed. This output will 
conduct a sector analysis of the ongoing health system challenges and will seek solutions to 
addressing Mongolia’s overall and broader medium- to long-term health system challenges. A 
series of assessments on foundational health system areas will be conducted and may include (i) 
pharmaceutical and vaccine regulation and quality, (ii) medicine procurement and affordability in 
public hospitals, (iii) public hospital management, (iv) health financing mechanisms to increase 
access to quality health services, (v) public−private partnerships in the health sector, (vi) public 
health  and  health  education,  and  (vii)  reproductive  health services  for  women  and  routine 
immunization  for  children.  Additional  assessments  may  also  be  conducted  on  managing 
availability of necessary medical equipment in public hospitals during emergencies. Gender 
analyses will be conducted in the assessments. Policy recommendations and an assessment of 
priority areas for investment and opportunity in the health sector will be prepared and submitted 
to MOH. The assessments will be conducted in close consultation with specialized organizations 
(e.g., WHO). 
 
 
10 ADB. Mongolia: Fifth Health Sector Development Project; ADB. Mongolia: COVID-19 Emergency Response - Phase 
2; ADB. Mongolia: Support for Improving the Preparedness and Response to Novel Coronavirus Outbreak; ADB. 
Mongolia: Fifth Health Sector Development Project; ADB. Mongolia: Shock-Responsive Social Protection Project; 
ADB. Mongolia: Second Shock-Responsive Social Protection Project; ADB. Mongolia: COVID-19 Rapid Response 
Program; ADB. Mongolia: Strengthening Health Security Program (Subprogram 1); ADB. Mongolia: Strengthening 
Rapid Epidemic Response Capacity of Health Systems Project; and ADB. Mongolia: Support for COVID-19 Vaccine 
Delivery in Mongolia under the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility. 
11 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
11.  Output 2: COVID-19 response and lessons documented. This output will take stock of 
the health sector’s COVID-19 response and produce a real-time evaluation of the successes and 
challenges in national pandemic management in order to urgently understand how to adjust and 
pivot policy decisions as the health emergency persists.12 The evaluation will also highlight 
gender issues. The evaluation will also be disseminated in the form of a knowledge product in 
English and Mongolian. A series of country consultations with development partners—such as 
the  World  Bank,  WHO,  United  Nations  Children’s  Fund  (UNICEF),  and  civil  society 
organizations—will be organized. 
 
12.  Output 3: Knowledge and skills of government agencies involved in COVID-19 
response strengthened. Under this output, training on topics identified through the real-time 
evaluation  of  the  COVID-19  response  will  be  organized.  Topics  may  include  the  incident 
management system, intersectoral information exchanges, intra-agency pandemic coordination, 
interagency  MOH  management,  and  addressing  vaccine  hesitancy  through  community 
mobilization efforts and effective health communication. Female representation will be ensured 
during the training, while gender sensitivities, especially for training areas such as vaccine 
hesitancy, will be incorporated in training modules. This output will also provide capacity building 
support to the National Emergency Management Agency, the General Agency for Specialized 
Inspection, and other agencies on pandemic management. Training for health specialists in public 
hospitals will also be provided. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $680,000, of which $650,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 7). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation 
and venue for meetings, counterpart staff, miscellaneous administration expenses, and other in-
kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB’s East Asia Department will select, supervise, and 
evaluate consultants; and organize workshops. Consultants will be recruited through individual 
consultant selection; a mix of international and national expertise will be needed. Implementation 
arrangements are summarized in the table.

15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated procurement staff instructions.13 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Mongolia for Strengthening COVID-19 Pandemic Response and Resilient Health 
Systems, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
13 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

disruptions in health services for women and children.
